msItemStruct.note: Written across the fibers; on the recto are traces of a prose literary work which has been cleaned off
Fragment (h) now preserves only 8 lines, not twelve as published in the ed. pr
The 12 lines of column (iv) are not wholly consecutive: (f) 10 lines from the top of the column, (g) 2 lines from the bottom of a column
Col. i, 16 lines; col. ii, 14 lines; col. iii, 28 lines; col. iv, 12 lines; col. v, 8 lines
Cols i-iii broken except at bottom; cols iv, v broken except at top
The hand is upright and rather large
Marks of elision have been written by the original scribe
Accents, breathings (usually acute-angled) and high stops have been added by a second hand, which has also introduced some corrections into the text
The system of accentuation is similar to that found in P.Oxy. 223
Cols. (i), (ii), (iii), (iv), and (v) in Princeton; the rest are in the Cornell collection, currently housed at the University of Michigan

The Princeton portions of the papyrus consist of eight fragments on which the text is preserved in the following manner: col. i, fragment (a); col. ii, fragment (b); col. iii, fragments (b), (c), (d), (e); col. iv, fragments (f), (g); col. v, fragment (h)

supportDesc.support: 5 papyrus fragments; (a) 12 x 7.5 cm. (b) 11 x 8.3 cm. (c) 8.8 x 3.5 cm. (d) 9.5 x 7.9 cm. (e) 5.7 x 4 cm. (f) 8.1 x 8.5 cm. (g) 4.2 x 3.6 cm. (h) 8.5 x 6.2 cm

provenance.p: Given to Princeton University by the Egypt Exploration Society, 1907

taxonomy.desc: APIS keywords are controlled locally at the institution level. They are not necessarily consistent.
